skills.name: Converting between expanded form and standard form (US) of a number up to 100,000
Given how many tens and ones, state the multiple of 10 up to 100
Identify how many tens in multiples of 10 up to 100 supported by bundle sticks

explanations.A: I think you might have your 10s and 1s mixed up! The first digit in 23 is tens.
explanations.B: Not quite - we need to think about the place value of each number. How could we represent that we have 2 tens?
explanations.C: There are 2 bundles of 10 here, which would be 20, then 3 individual sticks, which would be 3. This shows 23 in total!
explanations.D: Not quite - we need to think about the place value of each number. How could we represent that we have 3 ones?

explanations.A: There are 3 bundles of 10 here, which would be 30, then 2 individual sticks, which would be 2. This shows 32 in total!
explanations.B: Not quite - we need to think about the place value of each number. How could we represent that we have 3 tens?
explanations.C: I think you might have your 10s and 1s mixed up! The first digit in 32 is tens.
explanations.D: Not quite - we need to think about the place value of each number. How could we represent that we have 2 ones?

explanations.A: I think you might have your 10s and 1s mixed up! Place value increases from the right to left.
explanations.B: Place value increases from right to left, so the 6 is ones and the 4 is tens!
explanations.C: You're close, there are 4 tens in 46 but there aren't 60 ones! Remember to think about the digit in the place value column by itself!
explanations.D: You're close, there are 6 ones but there aren't 40 tens. Remember to think about the digit in the place value column by itself!

explanations.A: You're close, there are 8 ones but there aren't 50 tens. Remember to think about the digit in the place value column by itself!
explanations.B: I think you might have your 10s and 1s mixed up! Place value increases from the right to left.
explanations.C: Place value increases from right to left, so the 8 is ones and the 5 is tens!
explanations.D: You're close, there are 5 tens in 58 but there aren't 80 ones! Remember to think about the digit in the place value column by itself!

explanations.A: Ten lots of 10 is 10 x 10 which is 100!
explanations.B: That would be how much is in 1 bundle, but we are imagining that there are 10 of those bundles.
explanations.C: Not quite, this would be 10 bundles of 100 sticks, but there are only 10 sticks in this bundle!
explanations.D: I think you might have added another 10, which would only be the same as 2 bundles. We are trying to think of how many sticks there would be in total if we had 10 bundles like in the picture.

explanations.A: That would be how much is in 1 bundle, but we are imagining that there are 5 of those bundles.
explanations.B: Not quite, this would be 5 bundles of 100 sticks, but there are only 10 sticks in this bundle!
explanations.C: I think you've given the number of bundles rather than the number of sticks. If we had 5 bundles of 10 sticks, how many sticks would we have?
explanations.D: Five lots of 10 is 5 x 10 which is 50!

explanations.A: Not quite - if we had 100 bundles of 10, that'd be the same as 1000. We are trying to think of how many bundles like the one in the picture would give us 100 sticks in total!
explanations.B: 100 is 10 lots of 10, so we would need 10 bundles of 10 sticks to make 100 sticks in total.
explanations.C: The bundle in the picture has 10 sticks, so 1 of them would only be the same as having 10 sticks. How many of the bundles would we need to make 100 sticks?
explanations.D: I think you've given how many extra sticks we need to make 100, but we are thinking about how many bundles of 10 we would need to make 100!

explanations.A: 100 is 10 bundles of 10, and we have 1 already. Therefore we need another 9.
explanations.B: This is how many bundles we will need in total, but remember we already have one. How many more do we need?
explanations.C: This is how many more sticks we need, but how many bundles of 10 is this?
explanations.D: The bundle in the picture has 10 sticks, so 1 of them would only be the same as having 10 sticks. How many of the bundles would we need to make 100 sticks? How many more bundles is this?

explanations.A: That'd be the number that we make from 1 hundred and 4 tens, but we are trying to say how many tens that number would be!
explanations.B: 1 hundred and 4 tens is 140. 140 is the same as 14 tens!
explanations.C: I think you might have your tens and hundreds back to front here - hundreds would come before tens in a number, even though they're written back to front here!
explanations.D: I think you might have your tens and hundreds back to front here - hundreds would come before tens in a number, even though they're written back to front here! Remember that we're trying to see how many 10s this is equal to, as well!

explanations.A: I think you might have your tens and hundreds back to front here - hundreds would come before tens in a number, even though they're written back to front here! Remember that we're trying to see how many 10s this is equal to, as well!
explanations.B: I think you might have your tens and hundreds back to front here - hundreds would come before tens in a number, even though they're written back to front here!
explanations.C: 2 hundreds and 6 tens is 260. 260 is the same as 26 tens!
explanations.D: That'd be the number that we make from 2 hundreds and 6 tens, but we are trying to say how many tens that number would be!
